questions.question: At a local high school, GPA's are normally distributed with a mean of 2.9 and standard deviation of 0.6. What percentage of students at the high school have a GPA between 2.3 and 3.5?

explanations.a: Let X denote the GPA, therefore P(X in (2.3,3.5))=P(X in (-1,1))=phi(1)-phi(-1)=0.6826=68%.
explanations.b: Let X denote the GPA, therefore P(X in (2.3,3.5))=P(X in (-1,1))=phi(1)-phi(-1)=0.6826=68%.
explanations.c: Let X denote the GPA, therefore P(X in (2.3,3.5))=P(X in (-1,1))=phi(1)-phi(-1)=0.6826=68%.
explanations.d: Let X denote the GPA, therefore P(X in (2.3,3.5))=P(X in (-1,1))=phi(1)-phi(-1)=0.6826=68%.

questions.question: A mobile conversation follows a exponential distribution f (x) = (1/3)e-x/3. What is the probability that the conversation takes more than 5 minutes is?

explanations.a: f(x) = (1/3)e^(-x/3). The call should last more than 5 minutes so integrating from 5 till infinity we get the required probability = e^(-5/3).
explanations.b: f(x) = (1/3)e^(-x/3). The call should last more than 5 minutes so integrating from 5 till infinity we get the required probability = e^(-5/3).
explanations.c: f(x) = (1/3)e^(-x/3). The call should last more than 5 minutes so integrating from 5 till infinity we get the required probability = e^(-5/3).
explanations.d: f(x) = (1/3)e^(-x/3). The call should last more than 5 minutes so integrating from 5 till infinity we get the required probability = e^(-5/3).

questions.question: Consider a set of 18 samples from a standard normal distribution. We square each sample and sum all the squares. The number of degrees of freedom for a Chi Square distribution will be?

explanations.a: In Chi Square Distribution the number of standard normal derivatives or samples equals the number of degrees of freedom. Here total number of standard normal derivatives = 18. Hence the number of degrees of freedom for a Chi Square distribution = 18.
explanations.b: In Chi Square Distribution the number of standard normal derivatives or samples equals the number of degrees of freedom. Here total number of standard normal derivatives = 18. Hence the number of degrees of freedom for a Chi Square distribution = 18.
explanations.c: In Chi Square Distribution the number of standard normal derivatives or samples equals the number of degrees of freedom. Here total number of standard normal derivatives = 18. Hence the number of degrees of freedom for a Chi Square distribution = 18.
explanations.d: In Chi Square Distribution the number of standard normal derivatives or samples equals the number of degrees of freedom. Here total number of standard normal derivatives = 18. Hence the number of degrees of freedom for a Chi Square distribution = 18.

questions.question: The mean and the variance for gamma distribution are?

explanations.a: The mean and the variance for gamma distribution is given as E(X) = α/λ, Var(X) = a/λ^2.
explanations.b: The mean and the variance for gamma distribution is given as E(X) = α/λ, Var(X) = a/λ^2.
explanations.c: The mean and the variance for gamma distribution is given as E(X) = α/λ, Var(X) = a/λ^2.
explanations.d: The mean and the variance for gamma distribution is given as E(X) = α/λ, Var(X) = a/λ^2.

questions.question: Consider selecting 6 cards from a pack of cards without replacement. What is the probability that 3 of the cards will be black?

explanations.a: The given Experiment follows Hypergeometric distribution with N = 52 since there are 52 cards in a deck, k = 26 since there are 26 black cards in a deck, n = 6 since we randomly select 6 cards from the deck, x = 3 since 3 of the cards we select are black. Therefore, h(3; 52, 6, 26) = 0.3320 and thus, the probability of randomly selecting 6 black cards is 0.3320.
explanations.b: The given Experiment follows Hypergeometric distribution with N = 52 since there are 52 cards in a deck, k = 26 since there are 26 black cards in a deck, n = 6 since we randomly select 6 cards from the deck, x = 3 since 3 of the cards we select are black. Therefore, h(3; 52, 6, 26) = 0.3320 and thus, the probability of randomly selecting 6 black cards is 0.3320.
explanations.c: The given Experiment follows Hypergeometric distribution with N = 52 since there are 52 cards in a deck, k = 26 since there are 26 black cards in a deck, n = 6 since we randomly select 6 cards from the deck, x = 3 since 3 of the cards we select are black. Therefore, h(3; 52, 6, 26) = 0.3320 and thus, the probability of randomly selecting 6 black cards is 0.3320.
explanations.d: The given Experiment follows Hypergeometric distribution with N = 52 since there are 52 cards in a deck, k = 26 since there are 26 black cards in a deck, n = 6 since we randomly select 6 cards from the deck, x = 3 since 3 of the cards we select are black. Therefore, h(3; 52, 6, 26) = 0.3320 and thus, the probability of randomly selecting 6 black cards is 0.3320.
